statement.tex: \text{If the sixth term of an arithmetic}\\ \text{progression is 3 and the common difference}\\ \text{is }\beta,\text{then for what value of }\beta\text{ is the}\\ \text{product of the }\underline{\text{first, fourth and fifth}}\\ \text{terms the greatest?}

step.context: \textbf{Right or wrong?} \\ \text{If }a_1, a_4\text{ and }a_5\text{ be the first, fourth and fifth}\\ \text{terms respectively and P be their product,}\\ \text{then P will equal the following.}
step.reason: \text{The sixth term} = a_6 = 3.\\ \text{Hence, the first, fourth and fifth terms of}\\ \text{the }\underline{\text{arithmetic progression}}\text{ will be as follows}\\ \quad a_5 = 3-\beta, a_4 = 3-2\beta\text{ and }a_1 = 3-5\beta \\ \text{And therefore, }\\ \begin{align} P &= a_5\cdot a_4\cdot a_1 = (3-\beta)\cdot (3-2\beta)\cdot (3-5\beta) \\ &= (2\beta^2 - 9\beta + 9)\cdot (3-5\beta) \\ &= -10\beta^3 + 51\beta^2 - 72\beta + 27 \end{align}

step.context: \text{Given that extrema occurs when }\beta = 1,\dfrac{12}{5},\\ \textbf{is the following assertion correct?}
step.tex: \underline{\text{The smaller }\beta\text{ is}} \text{, the larger }a_1,a_4\text{ and }a_5\\ \text{would be. And so also their product - P.}\\ \text{Hence, P will be maximum when }\beta = 1.
step.reason: \textbf{The only sure test for maxima/minima is }\dfrac{d^2 P}{d\beta^2}.\\ \begin{align} \dfrac{dP}{d\beta} &= -30\beta^2 + 102\beta - 72 \\ \implies\dfrac{d^P}{d\beta^2} &= -60\beta + 102 \\ \implies \underbrace{\dfrac{d^2P}{d\beta^2} \lt 0}_{\text{condition for maxima}} &\text{ if } -60\beta + 102 \lt 0 \\ \implies \beta &\gt \dfrac{102}{60} = \dfrac{17}{10} \end{align} \\ \text{Of the two values of }\beta,\text{ only }\beta=\dfrac{12}{5}\\ \text{satisfies this condition. Hence, the product P}\\ \text{is maximum when }\beta = \dfrac{12}{5}.
